l n 1581 Richard Mulcaster, the Elizabethan schoolmaster, saw published the first of his two important treatises which together attempt, but fail, to do what Quintilian did for Roman education—to sum up conventional practice and to lay down a foundation (he calls it a “plat'’ or platform) for the future structure of English education. Mulcaster is concerned with the intellectual development of children from about four or five, when they might begin to read, through grammar school, until they are ready to move on to the university.
